title: Brit couple who 'arranged murder of adopted son, 11, for £150,000' fight extradition

A British couple accused of organising the murder of their adopted son so they could pocket an insurance payout are fighting moves for them to face trial in India.

Arti Dhir, 55, and Kaval Raijada, 30, have denied paying someone to kidnap and stab orphan Gopal Sejani in Gujarat so they could claim £150,000 insurance.

Britain has refused to extradite the couple on human rights grounds but the Indian government has now been granted leave to appeal.

Indian authorities say the pair, who have no children of their own, adopted the tragic orphan after placing an advert in a local newspaper.

The advert promised they would take a child to live a better life in London if their application was successful.

The couple, from Hanwell, west London, were introduced to poverty-stricken farm boy Gopal who was living with his older sister and her husband Harsukh Kardani and began preparing adoption papers.

But Indian police claim the adoption was a ruse for them to carry out their alleged insurance plan.

They say Ms Dhir took out a £150,000 policy in Gopal's name which would would pay out after 10 years or if he died.

(Image: GUJURAT POLICE)

Superintendent Saurab Singh, of Junagadh Police in Gujarat, said: "After a few days she took out an insurance policy in his name.

"It was a huge amount and she paid two premiums, knowing very well that in the event of Gopal's death, she would be paid 10 times the insured amount."

The couple returned home to London without Gopal who stayed in Gujarat while visa papers were arranged for him.

But in February 2017 he was kidnapped by two men on motorbikes, stabbed and left at the roadside.

His brother-in-law, Mr Kardani was also attacked as he tried to save him.

Both died from their injuries.

Police arrested a suspect who was said to be a friend of the couple who had spent time with them when he was studying in London.

Three other men have also been held by Indian police.

Indian authorities say there had been two previous attempts on Gopal's life.

Ms Dhir, a worker at Heathrow airport, and Mr Raijada face six charges in India, including conspiracy to murder and kidnapping.

(Image: BBC)

They were arrested in the UK in June 2017 after a request from the Indian government but a judge at Westminster Magistrates' Court refused their extradition.

The move was blocked because the penalty for double murder in Gujarat is life in prison without parole.

Because a lesser term would be imposed in the UK this sentence is seen as a human rights breach.

The Indian authorities' appeal is expected to be heard in the New Year.

Outside the couple's home Ms Dhir refused to say why they won't travel to India to stand trial.

The couple deny the allegations.

The insurance policy was never paid out.
description: Arti Dhir, 55, and Kaval Raijada, 30, from Hanwell, west London, deny paying someone to kidnap and stab Gopal Sejani in Gujarat so they could claim an insurance payout
